Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I could see the pain in his eyes as he called me, his voice trembling, barely holding together. He needed me—needed my words, my presence, my comfort. I wanted nothing more than to drop everything and be there for him, to hold his hand and let him know he wasn’t alone. But I was standing behind the register, the line of customers growing, the clock ticking toward the end of my shift. The manager had just reminded me how crucial it was to double-check every bill and receipt tonight; one mistake could mean hours of paperwork and a loss I’d have to explain. My phone buzzed again in my pocket, his name lighting up the screen. My heart ached, torn between the urge to answer and the responsibility to keep my focus sharp. Each beep of the scanner felt heavier, my hands trembling as I tried to count change, my mind split between the numbers in front of me and the pain on the other end of the line. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding more than I could give.
